qas.question: What group divided the world into two parts?
Into what parts did the Pasupatas divide the world?
In what staet was the insentient considered to be?
How was the sentient seen as being?
For the Pasupatas, how was the union of the soul with God achieved?
What was the sentient dependent on?
Salvation required the soul separating from what?
What was the sentient broken up into?
How many effects made up the sentient?

plausible_answers.text: the illusive identification of Self with non-Self

qas.question: What were the effects responsible for?

context: <a0_0>Pāśupatas<a0_0/> divided the created world into <b5_0>the <a1_0>insentient<b5_0/> and the sentient<a1_0/>. The insentient was the <a2_0>unconscious<a2_0/> and thus dependent on the sentient or <a3_0>conscious<a3_0/>. The insentient was further divided into <b7_0>effects and causes<b7_0/>. The effects were of <b8_0>ten<b8_0/> kinds, the earth, four elements and their qualities, colour etc. The causes were of thirteen kinds, the five organs of cognition, the five organs of action, the three internal organs, intellect, the ego principle and the cognising principle. These insentient causes were held responsible for <b9_0>the illusive identification of Self with non-Self<b9_0/>. Salvation in Pāśupata involved the union of the soul with <b6_0>God <a4_0>through the intellect<b6_0/><a4_0/>.
